oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Genetic and Antigenic Characterization of Bovine Viral Diarrhea Field Isolates
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hause, B. M.
Bey, R. F.
Stine, D. L.
Simonson, R. R.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Bovine viral diarrhea virus
BVDV
vaccines
genotype
field isolates
E2 gene
antigenic methods
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is commonly found in cattle and causes significant economic losses. Despite long term and widespread use of commercial modified live vaccines, BVD remains problematic. BVDV are classified into two genotypes, BVDV-1 and BVDV-2, and are further subdivided within the genotype by sequence analysis. Most genetic analysis is performed on the 5'-untranslated region of the genome as it is relatively conserved, however, this region does not code for an antigen. The objective of this study was to characterize recent BVDV field isolates using genetic analysis of the E2 gene in combination with antigenic methods using antisera generated against multiple isolates in a high throughput serum neutralization assay.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2010; 219
